items.title: Ckeditor box doesn't show the content and doesn't let me to write (admin panel)
items.body:
Hi, I downloaded the latest version of Ckeditor (5.9.0) for django (2.2.6). After installing the module and adding to the INSTALLED_APP, I executed this command "python3 manage.py collectstatic". Then, I changed the TextField of my Model to RichTextField and I executed these commands: "python3 manage.py makemigrations" , "python3 manage.py migrate".

In admin panel, when i try to add a new entity of this model, in the corresponding field, shows a ckeditor box, but with white content and doesn't let me to write something. When I click "Source code" , I can write text, but when I switch it off, the content appears for a while and then disappears. Also, the buttons of editors when I click them, their content disappears.

items.title: Add Django template tags into RichTextField and then render the HTML
iframes disappear when saving again or switching between views
items.body:
**How to reproduce the issue:** in source view, add an iframe code; for instance: `
mwhiteside · Repercussive (2017) - Matthew Whiteside
` Switching to normal edit view and then saving nullifies the iframe already. Saving while still in source view retains the iframe. After saving in source view (therefore having the iframe working on the front end) and entering in edit mode again and then saving the form (whether in source view or normal view) makes the iframe disappear. I suppose because the editor enters in normal view by default and not in source view. The iframe only works if we remain in source view all the time. See also #223 , which is closed although it doesn't seem to have been solved.

items.title: custom template for ckeditor widget
items.body:
hey, as far as I went through the code it looks like the path to template which is used to render the widget (`ckeditor/widget.html`) is hardcoded in the widget. I know I can subclass the `CKEditorWidget` but overwriting the render method just to change the template slightly (removing the `style="display: inline-block;"`), seems a bit uncomfortable.

Would it make sense to move template path to a variable that it can be simple overwritten with `template = 'ckeditor/custom_widget.html'`?

items.title: Nitpick: Avoid calling the widget a RichTextField
items.body:
Rich text hearkens back the days of the rich text format (rtf) that was popular before HTML. I had to double-check that this widget does not, in fact, store data in rtf, but, rather, HTML. I'm new to CKEditor, so I am not sure what it is actually capable of.

I understand that this a nitpick and probably not worth the headache it will cause for legacy users. Nevertheless, I raise this issue to bring the naming of things to the forefront of our brains.

The django-tinymce package actually uses HTMLField, which is what it is. It's not a rich text field.

items.title: Rendered template doesn't show same styling.
items.body:
When I'm editing content in ckeditor, it looks great with all the styling applied. For example, code snippet looks like:

[![ckeditor editor content.][1]][1]


and blockquote looks like: 
[![content displayed in browser][2]][2]


But when django template(content) is rendered it doesn't preserve any of the styling.

Code snippets becomes :[![content displayed inside ckeditor][3]][3]

and blockquote becomes :
[![content displayed in browser][4]][4]

Both, code snippet and blockquote in rendered template looks far different from the wysiwyg editor.


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/q4ZZb.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/JcuuV.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/vIzZJ.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZN6MF.png

items.title: Static files not working
items.body:
I'm using `django-ckeditor 5.8.0`

`settings.py`
```
CKEDITOR_CONFIGS = {
    'default': {
        'skin': 'moono',
        'width': '100%',
        'toolbar_Basic': [
            ['Source', '-', 'Bold', 'Italic']
        ],
        'toolbar_YourCustomToolbarConfig': [
            {'name': 'document', 'items': [
                'Source', '-', 'Save', 'Preview', '-', 'Templates']},
            {'name': 'clipboard', 'items': [
                'Cut', 'Copy', 'Paste', 'PasteText', 'PasteFromWord', '-', 'Undo', 'Redo']},
            {'name': 'editing', 'items': [
                'Find', 'Replace', '-', 'SelectAll']},
            '/',
            {'name': 'basicstyles',
             'items': ['Bold', 'Italic', 'Underline', 'Strike', 'Subscript', 'Superscript', '-', 'RemoveFormat']},
            {'name': 'paragraph',
             'items': ['NumberedList', 'BulletedList', '-', 'Outdent', 'Indent', '-', 'Blockquote', 'CreateDiv', '-',
                       'JustifyLeft', 'JustifyCenter', 'JustifyRight', 'JustifyBlock', '-', 'BidiLtr', 'BidiRtl',
                       'Language']},
            {'name': 'links', 'items': ['Link', 'Unlink', 'Anchor']},
            {'name': 'insert',
             'items': ['Image', 'Flash', 'Table', 'HorizontalRule', 'Smiley', 'SpecialChar', 'PageBreak', 'Iframe']},
            '/',
            {'name': 'styles', 'items': [
                'Styles', 'Format', 'Font', 'FontSize']},
            {'name': 'colors', 'items': ['TextColor', 'BGColor']},
            {'name': 'tools', 'items': ['Maximize', 'ShowBlocks']},
            {'name': 'about', 'items': ['About']},
            '/',
            {'name': 'yourcustomtools', 'items': [
                'CodeSnippet',
            ]},
        ],
        'toolbar': 'YourCustomToolbarConfig',
        'tabSpaces': 4,
        'extraPlugins': ','.join([
            'uploadimage',
            'codesnippet',
        ]),
    }
}
```

`models`:
 ```
content = RichTextUploadingField()
```

CKEditor's `static` files are served in admin mode but the `css` file(`contents.css`) doesn't load in other `views` elsewhere. 

I'm using `ManifestStaticFilesStorage` and after running `collectstatic`, files exist where it should.

I've also added three line in the template:
```
<script>window.CKEDITOR_BASEPATH = "{% static '/ckeditor/ckeditor/' %}";</script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="{% static 'ckeditor/ckeditor-init.js' %}" data-ckeditor-basepath="{% static 'ckeditor/ckeditor/' %}" id="ckeditor-init-script"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="{% static 'ckeditor/ckeditor/ckeditor.js' %}"></script>
```

Here's the image of the `html` from the `browser` :

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26048398/71763168-92577f00-2efe-11ea-9a76-dbf5b3c42b3c.png)

Clicking on those two `js` files also shows its content, meaning they are accessible. 

`contents.css` file isn't loaded, hence no styling. 

Same story on the `development` server too.

Any suggestions will be appreciated.

items.body:
I'm using django=1.11.X and restful framework, python3, win10. When I finished configing ckeditor, it won't show anything(just blank as showed below).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20840761/58756827-7045ea80-8532-11e9-9c9d-e214954336c6.png)

`    url(r'^ckeditor/', include('ckeditor_uploader.urls')),`

settings.py
`CKEDITOR_UPLOAD_PATH = 'ckupload/'`

models.py
```
class Info(models.Model):
    """
    XX
    """
    content = RichTextField(config_name='awesome_ckeditor')

```

At first, I thought it had something to do with web browsers, so I've tried Chrome, Firefox and Edge. But the results were the same. Then, I uninstalled django-ckeditor and reinstalled, still no luck.

This problem has bothered me for months and oddly, sometimes it works. I literally have no idea why it happens.

Hopefully, someone will figure that out. Thanks in advance.

items.title: Why do we need migration when changing TextField -> RichTextField ?
items.body:
When I change from `TextField` -> `RichTextField` (without changing any `blank`, `null` etc)
it generates this migration 

    import ckeditor.fields
    from django.db import migrations

    class Migration(migrations.Migration):

        dependencies = [
            ('mail', '0006_some_previous_migration'),
        ]

        operations = [
            migrations.AlterField(
                model_name='message',
                name='body_html',
                field=ckeditor.fields.RichTextField(blank=True, null=True),
            ),
        ]


Which doesn't change db (PostgreSQL) structure at ALL

Why do we need it ? Thx !

items.title: [XXS - CVSS Score 6.5] Update ckeditor to 4.11.4
items.body:
> CKEditor 4.11 fixes an XSS vulnerability in the HTML parser reported by maxarr. The vulnerability stemmed from the fact that it was possible to execute XSS inside the CKEditor source area after persuading the victim to: (i) switch CKEditor to source mode, then (ii) paste a specially crafted HTML code, prepared by the attacker, into the opened CKEditor source area, and (iii) switch back to WYSIWYG mode. Although this is an unlikely scenario, we recommend to upgrade to the latest editor version.
https://ckeditor.com/blog/CKEditor-4.11-with-emoji-dropdown-and-auto-link-on-typing-released/

### How to find vulnerabilities
https://retirejs.github.io/retire.js/

### More information on Snyk 
https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-CKEDITOR-72618

### Also solves
https://github.com/django-ckeditor/django-ckeditor/issues/540

items.title: Serving media files with GCS backend
items.body:
I'm currently using a GCS bucket as a static and media backend. Both are in a shared bucket, and I wrote a small backend class to separate static files from media files in their own subdirectories.

Static files work perfectly fine and end up in the right place (e.g. <assets-bucket/static>). I'm using the RichTextUploadingField() to allow users to upload images to the bucket and use them. Uploading works fine using the google storage api, (files end up in <assets-bucket/media/upload/../..>) but it generates a URL to the media file which includes a expire-token.

Serving the media file is fine, as long as the token isn't expired. After a while the image isn't being served anymore, because the auto-generated URL has become invalid.

I set up a Cloud CDN, which has its dedicated URL and loadbalancer for serving the media files from the assets bucket. However, I can't seem to make it work that the ckeditor uses this URL, instead of the auto-generated one when an image is embedded.

1. Is there a way that the ckeditor doesn't generate a url with an expire-token?
2. Can I somehow configure the ckeditor to upload through the storage api, and serve/embed through the dedicated Cloud CDN url/loadbalancer?

items.title: admin inline 'add another' disappears
items.body:
HI all,

If I add ckeditor to a tabular inline in the django admin, the 'add another' link at the bottom of the inline disappears. Is there any fix available?

EDIT: using a ckeditor anywhere on the admin change page removes the 'add another' link of all inlines on the change page. I guess it is some sort of javascript conflict but I'm not sure how to solve this (properly).

EDIT 2: In chromium console I get following error:
```
inlines.js:20 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'fn' of undefined
    at inlines.js:20
    at inlines.js:298
```

EDIT 3: It is due to jquery that is not yet loaded when the inlines.js script is run. I found a [hacky fix on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50707750/django-admin-stackedinline-not-loading-add-another-model-uncaught-typeerror-ca) (wait 300ms to call inlines.js basically). However, there must be a better solution.


ckeditor version 5.6.1
django version 2.1

Thanks!

items.title: README, static files path issue.
items.body:
Hey, followed installation and in my case I had to add / on the end of below:

CKEDITOR_BASEPATH = "/my_static/ckeditor/ckeditor"

I am not sure if you wrote the readme file for different version of django/python but above is not returning errors without / on the end in my project.

Also thank you so much, this is great!

items.title: script tag with django-js-assets causing problems
items.body:
Hello,

we upgraded django-ckeditor to a newer version. This version uses django-js-assets, causing problems in js/css path handling.

https://github.com/matthiask/django-js-asset/blob/master/js_asset/js.py#L60

this replaces the url with a kind of html

`static/js/some.js`
is converted to
`static/js/some.js" id="abv" data-example="something`
watch out for the quoting marks

Our problem: absolute_path() normally returns a url, so we can append a timestamp `?v=123456798` for cache optimization. Now we add the timestamp incorrectly to the end of `data-example`.

I dont know the reason for using django-js-assets / adding things to script tag, but in my oppinion, this is not a very good solution at the moment

items.title: CKEditor allows script tags (code injection)
items.body:
I am using a fresh install of CKEditor on Django 2.1 and python 3. I'm using it with django-machina, but I don't think that should matter.

To clarify here is exactly what I did:
- pip install'd django-ckeditor
- followed the instructions on this page exactly to edit settings.py: https://django-machina.readthedocs.io/en/stable/customization/recipes/using_another_markup_language.html 

When I tested it out, it allowed me to write Javascript in a forum post by switching to "Source" mode and submitting. The Javascript runs in the post.

I tried to change this by adding the following to `settings.py`: 

```
CKEDITOR_CONFIGS = {
    'default': {
        "removePlugins": "stylesheetparser",
        "allowedContent": False,
    }
};
```

The javascript still ran in the post. I don't know how to disable this. (Is there a way?)

From issue #245 I infer that this is not intended behavior (That issue makes it sound like CKEditor has HTML cleaning by default and thus shouldn't be allowing script tags on a fresh install) If this has actually been changed intentionally, I'd like to argue that this is a security risk and should be changed back to filter it by default. 

Thank you and please let me know if you need more information.

items.title: State the Django minimum supported version in the Readme

It took me quite some times to understand why it wasn't working on my project running Django 1.8 only to later find on pypi.org that the minimum supported version since 5.6.0 is Django 1.11 LTS, it would be nice to have it in the Readme so that it is easily found.

Nevertheless, awesome package, thank you!

items.title: CKEditor getUrl cache issue - modify timestamp on deploy?
items.body:
Hey there!

CKEditor's [`getUrl()` method](https://docs.ckeditor.com/ckeditor4/latest/api/CKEDITOR.html#method-getUrl) adds a so called timestamp to every link it processes. It's meant to help update cached static files when the lib gets updated, or a new bundle of the same version is downloaded from their site.

However the [timestamp](https://docs.ckeditor.com/ckeditor4/latest/api/CKEDITOR.html#property-timestamp) appears to hard-coded in CKEditor's JS. Which leads to the caching problem being even worse if one only updates some static files without redownloading/updating CKEditor. For example, if we're developing custom plugins and push changes to their JS and CSS from time to time - these files' cached versions don't get cleared.

My question is: is there a method in django-ckeditor to solve that? I can think of generating some unique value on each deploy and set the `CKEDITOR.timestamp` prop to that value (and have it empty on a dev environment). How do you overcome this issue?

items.title: ckeditor_uploader/browse.html not found
items.body:
The issue come from: 
_def browse(request)_ in _ckeditor_uploader/views.py_ 
When I tried to use ckeditor_uploader, the view isn't able to find the file _browse.html_ when I was trying to upload an image on my server. To fix it, I modified the render, like so: 
before --> return render(request, 'ckeditor_uploader/browse.html', context)
my fix --> return render(request, 'ckeditor/browse.html', context)

In fact, in _ckeditor/templates/_ & _ckeditor_uploader/templates/_ both have subdirectory called _ckeditor_ and we tried to call _'ckeditor_uploader/browse.html'_ instead of _'ckeditor/browse.html'_.

Maybe this is due to an incorrect configuration on my project ? Because, I'm not the first guys who tried to use the uploader, isn't it ? I found this topic, it seems to be the same issue than #467 

Thanks anyway for this great framework you have made :) !

items.title: Using editor changes the style of the template
items.body:
Hello, beginner issue I'm afraid. This is the 3rd WYSIWIG editor I have installed and is the best so far in terms of ease of installation and use. However, When I go to use it on my blog app it completely changes the styling of the templates where the output is being displayed (I did see this behaviour with the two other WYSIWYG editors, amongst other strange issues that lead me to uninstall them). 

I'm now into my second day of trying to find out what the problem is and fix it, but I'm not getting very far, although, adding |safe to the template is what appears to trigger the change (I know I need |safe here as leaving the HTML is not an option). I have attached an image of what the page looks like before and after adding |safe: 
Before |safe
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35370046/37419121-acefeed0-27ab-11e8-9d19-605eaebb24ed.png)

After |safe:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35370046/37419243-e5782240-27ab-11e8-80c8-155efb479aa3.png)

In the after |safe image the card has moved from being in the row down to the column and the text is red, even though it is set as black in the editor itself.

I am using Django 2.0.2 & Python 3.4.6. My styling uses Bootstrap 4, the list view of the blog is using cards in a 3 column x 4 row format. I am using a forloop to generate this.

I realise this is not necessarily specific to CKeditor given that I've seen this with other editors, but if you have any ideas that would really be appreciated as currently I'm getting fed up of banging my head against a brick wall. It's either a compatibility issue, or I'm missing something very simple.

```
CKEDITOR_CONFIGS = {
    'default': {
        'toolbar': 'full',
    },
}
```

Why is that? How can i prevent it?

If i want to edit and save an entry in django admin (containing a german Umlaut [ü]), it will cause an error:

```

        include('ckeditor_uploader.urls')),
```

items.title: Misleading error: ImproperlyConfigured: django-ckeditor requires CKEDITOR_MEDIA_PREFIX setting
items.body:
In widgets.py there is a try block where any AttributeError that happens inside of that results in this error:

https://github.com/django-ckeditor/django-ckeditor/blob/17d89a2ef7efdf91fb266ed84031f6cf2693b07e/ckeditor/widgets.py#L61-L78

CKEDITOR_BASEPATH is what is being checked, but with a getattr and a default. CKEDITOR_MEDIA_PREFIX is not being checked at all.

In my case CKEDITOR_MEDIA_PREFIX and CKEDITOR_BASEPATH are set and I still have no idea what is wrong.

It must be something inside js_assets.

I don't think you need that try block at all. The setting that is being checked already has a default. The error message is probably left over from a previous implementation.
